title: What did Donald Trump say about Kurds and why has he withdrawn troops from Syria?
text:
The withdrawal of US troops has left the Kurds vulnerable to attack (Picture: Jabin Botsford/The Washington Post/Getty)

President Donald Trump has defended his decision to withdraw US troops from Syria, enabling Turkish forces to launch an attack on Kurdish fighters.

Turkey began its operation on Wednesday with airstrikes hitting northern Syria before troops advanced across the border.

Why has Donald Trump pulled US troops from Syria?

Trump insisted the attack was a ‘bad idea’ after it was announced by Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

On Monday he issued a message to Erdogan in which he threatened to ‘totally destroy and obliterate’ the country if the offensive was to go ahead.

He tweeted: ‘As I have stated strongly before, and just to reiterate, if Turkey does anything that I, in my great and unmatched wisdom, consider to be off limits, I will totally destroy and obliterate the Economy of Turkey (I’ve done before!).’

….the captured ISIS fighters and families. The U.S. has done far more than anyone could have ever expected, including the capture of 100% of the ISIS Caliphate. It is time now for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory. THE USA IS GREAT! — Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) October 7, 2019

The president called on Turkey watch over the captured IS fighters being held in Syria while apparently urging Kurdish forces retaliate against them.

He tweeted: ‘It is time now for others in the region, some of great wealth, to protect their own territory. THE USA IS GREAT!’

What has Donald Trump said about Kurdish fighters?

The Kurds have been the US’ only ally in fighting IS and have stood alongside Americans for five years.

Trump defended the apparent abandonment of Kurdish forces stating they did not fight alongside the US during the Second World War.

Turkey said is offensive against the Kurds was to bring peace to the area (Picture: Burak Kara/Getty)

He argued it was not a situation for the US to get involved with as it was a ‘fight for land’.

He said: ‘We have spent a tremendous amount of money helping the Kurds.

‘They’re fighting for their land. When you say they’re fighting with the US, yes. But they’re fighting for their land.’

Last year the president vowed to stand by Kurds saying they had ‘fought with us’ and ‘died’ with us.

Why does Turkey want to invade Syria?

Erdogan claimed the attack will help ‘eradicate the threat of terror’ to his country by creating a ‘safe zone’.

This will push Kurdish forces away from the southern border and eventually allow two million Syrian refugees to return to the area, the president said.

The move has sparked criticism around the world with fears it could lead to a resurgence of IS, not least because the Kurds halted operations against the extremists to turn their attention to the Turkish troops.

Kurdish forces have warned of a ‘humanitarian catastrophe’ (Picture; Bulent Kilic/AFP?Getty)

Tense relations between Turkey and the Kurds have been long-standing and date back decades.

Recent years has seen the country embroiled in conflict with the Kurdistan’s Workers Party (PKK) over its hopes of securing an independent Kurdish state within the country.

The PKK, established in 1984, is considered a terrorist organisation by Turkey, the US and the UK, among other nations.

Formed in 2004, the Kurdish People’s Protection Units (YPG) has been at the forefront of the battle against IS.

However it too is seeking an independent Kurdish state and its rising presence along the border has been seen as a threat to Turkey.
